Keith Jarvis, senior security researcher at Sophos' Counter Threat Unit joins Dark Reading's Alex Culafi for a conversation you don't want to miss.Dark Reading Staff, Dark ReadingAugust 28, 2025Becky BrackenHello, everyone, and welcome to Dark Reading Confidential. It's a podcast from the editors of Dark Reading, bringing you real stories straight from the cyber trenches. I'm your host and Dark Reading editor, Becky Bracken. For this episode, I'm joined by Dark Reading senior reporter Alex Culafi, and Keith Jarvis, who's senior security researcher at Sophos' Counter Threat Unit. They will be giving us a guided tour of today's Dark Web. Welcome, Alex and Keith.Alexander CulafiThank you.Keith JarvisThank you.Becky BrackenWe're really excited. Go ahead, Alex, take it away. Give us our tour.Alexander CulafiAll right. Thanks, Becky. And thanks to Keith for joining us today. We are going to be doing a guided tour through the Dark Web, which is a boogeyman of a term that refers to the sites and content that require special Web browsers to access. They reside on overlay networks.You probably know these sites as where folks buy illegal substances or get scammed. But in cybersecurity, it is where a lot of these ransomware data leak sites are. It is where folks buy a lot of malware kits. There are hacking forums like RAMP — folks sell stolen data and credentials, and so on. It's a complicated thing. And today, I thought it would be great for Keith to join us so we could sort of walk through the cybersecurity piece of it, how researchers and defenders use it, how cybercriminals use it, and how things have changed. Keith, how does your professional life interact with the Dark Web, and how long have you been researching it?Related:Anyone Using Agentic AI Needs to Understand Toxic FlowsKeith JarvisRight, so it's increasingly important. It's something that we've been monitoring in the threat intelligence space for well over a decade now. You know, to the Tor network, the largest anonymity network out there, which is really sort of synonymous with the Dark Web, has been around for decades. But it's only been over the last 10, 15 years that cybercriminals have really fled there from other platforms.So, more and more we're seeing the open communication that's happening between cybercriminals happening on the Tor network and sometimes different networks like ITP, but pretty infrequently. And that's, I think, getting a lot more prevalent now that we're starting to see other forums like Telegram starting to clamp down on open criminality that's been the order of things for the last several decades. We see more cybercriminals moving into what I think is a safer space for them to operate.Alexander CulafiWhen I think about the Dark Web as a term and I think about the idea of things like Dark Web monitoring or whatever on the vendor side, "Dark Web" is a very scary term. But when I think about the threat actor side, the last time I looked into it, it was a lot of leak sites. It was a lot of forums. It was a lot of hackers communicating in ways where they assume they'll remain anonymous. Have things mostly stayed the same in the last few years, or have things changed at all?Related:Federal Cuts Put Local, State Agencies at Cyber-RiskKeith JarvisYeah, it's definitely the platform of choice for ransomware groups, overwhelmingly. So 90%-plus of them, when they're leaking data, when they're exposing victims that they've compromised, they'll be doing that on the Tor network. Now, a few of them do maintain what we call clear net sites on the public Internet, on the Web, that any person can access, but it's more and more infrequent that that's happening.And I think it's just an easy way for them to observe a little bit of operational security. They can put a site up quite easily on the Tor network. They can publish data there. And they, for the most part, don't have to worry about the traditional threats of domain takedowns, either through abuse complaints through their provider or, more importantly, through law enforcement action. The last thing they want to do is get identified by law enforcement where they're operating from, even if it's just their website, and have that as a means of sort of attributing them. So if they can do one less thing that puts them out there publicly, they're going to make that choice. And it's not just ransomware groups. It's a lot of other groups you mentioned earlier at the top of the podcast about the drug market. It's been the place where people go to trade in illicit substances, and has been for a very long time. One of the key features of Tor network in many people's minds is the ability to go to these sort of bazaars and find out whatever drug that they're interested in doing, maybe even some drugs they're not interested in doing, but they're there and they're for sale. It's a curiosity for many people, but it's also a way for people to replace their real-life drug dealers and so forth.Related:Chinese Hackers Game Google to Boost Gambling SitesAnd there's other things on there. Like you said, there's malware for sale in certain marketplaces. Cybercriminals, a lot of their forums have at least put up a presence on these Dark Web sites. But frequently, they also run out of clear Web sites. It's a little bit of both. But I think we're seeing more and more traffic moving into these networks.Alexander CulafiWhen a victim gets compromised and their data gets exfiltrated and that data or those credentials go up for sale, I would imagine that even if there are clear Web options, the complexities of how a lot of these hidden services work and a lot of these Dark Net markets work mean that that's probably going to be the first place where a lot of threat actors are going to try to offload whatever they've picked up during a data exfiltration attack.Keith JarvisYeah, that's right. I mean, we know that the credential markets, you know, like one of the largest ones is called Russian Market, and it has a large presence on the Tor network. Genesis in the past was another one. They also maintain, you know, sort of dual connectivity. And I think it's twofold right there. These threat actors are trying to preserve their own operational and personal security, so they don't get attributed and then arrested — the worst-case scenario for them.But they're also trying to give a little bit of comfort to the people who are their clients, right? They want to make sure that they know that, 'We're on the Tor network, you need to access to the Tor network.' So not only is it protecting us, but it's also protecting the people that are coming there and making purchases. You're not coming over the public Internet where you've got all sorts of intelligence agencies and law enforcement agencies doing signals intelligence on everything that goes across the Internet. It's a comfort thing for both buyers and for sellers.Alexander CulafiWhen I think about a lot of these takedowns that have happened in the last few years, whether it's the highly public LockBit one or another one of the ones that we see pop up maybe every three, four, five, six months, it feels like they're happening a lot more frequently than they did maybe five or six years ago when I started covering cybersecurity. Is that more up to law enforcement getting more aggressive? Or is the Dark Web not as anonymous as it used to be and folks are getting around that better? Like how do you explain this increase in law enforcement activity we're seeing?Keith JarvisRight. So there has been an increased tempo from law enforcement to go after these groups for good reason, right? It was just ransomware as an epidemic for IT departments throughout the world. Traditionally, Western Europe and the US really had to worry about it in the mid-2010s. But now you go on these leak sites and it's going to be everywhere from Latin America to Southeast Asia. A lot of people in a lot of places are now really concerned about it. You see a lot of international task force cooperation between these agencies and they really know that they need to make a dent on this because their economies are at risk from just letting this ransomware threat be so pervasive. But I think it's one aspect of a criminal organization, this public website where they're publishing data, but there's so much more to these organizations than just where they're publishing data.While that complicates attribution and tracking to a great degree, it's having those sites out there, they're still having to interact with other cybercriminals and they're doing that through peer-to-peer messaging, they're doing that through forums. When they're receiving ransom payments, those are going through, if not the traditional banking system, then it's going through Bitcoin exchanges and changers and so forth.And that's where I think the most attribution is happening right there, the traditional sort of police work of going after the individuals and maybe they're able to identify where those leak sites are actually located, even if they're on the Tor network. But one of the key things that we've seen with this law enforcement action is that while they really go after the individual, a key outcome there is for them to secure the private keys that let them run those Tor networks. That way they can take over those sites and either post the "this site has been seized" type information, which you can't do without accessing the original server or having those private keys available or running those as a honeypot and seeing who comes there looking for the data. If they're running an affiliate program for their ransomware operation, it lets them see who's accessing those panels, and it lets them expose the broader network that's going on behind the scenes. It's definitely working to the benefit of cybercriminals to have this technology available to them.Alexander CulafiBut it does sound like that even though the technological side has maybe improved in some ways in how researchers and law enforcement sort of approach tackling crime on these hidden services, Dark Net sites, whatever, a lot of it is conventional detective, police work. I think back to 10, 15 years ago, when it was the Silk Road and there were these social engineering things where they were posing as members on forums in order to gain sensitive information that law enforcement could later act on.I also know that a lot of researchers will try to make accounts on new hacking forums when they pop up so that they can get in there, see what's going on. I would even count tracing back Bitcoin mixers to try to find out where the source comes from.Do you find that still what a lot of your research and the research of those around you consists of a lot of old school step-by-step detective work?Keith JarvisYeah, absolutely. And if you look at the details of the Silk Road, you know how law enforcement was able to go after that organization. It was from the early days when he was advertising on, you know, clear net forums and saying, Come check out this site. And then eventually he realized that that's not going to work out for me from a personal security perspective. He moved entirely to a lot better security for himself.But in the end, once the spotlight is on you from law enforcement's perspective, they're going to use all of that data going back to your early days to try and attribute that marketplace to a person. And that's what they did there. So, I think what we see today is a lot of criminals, they start small and they're quite content to be on Telegram or some other type of forum. But when they really start to grow, to broaden their operations, that's when they start to think about, Well, maybe I shouldn't do things this way because it puts me at risk.But by then, the Internet doesn't forget, right? All that data is still there. Researchers like myself or law enforcement agencies, we have access to that. If we're not collecting it, we can go search for it and find it. And those early breadcrumbs are often what lead to the big reveals, the big investigative moments where we say, this is connected to that. And it's because they made early mistakes when they rightfully thought that nobody was looking at them, because nobody was looking at them.But it wasn't until a spotlight really got bright when they reached a certain level of notoriety that what they were doing early became important.Alexander CulafiThe last time I looked into what was happening on the Dark Web was I think 2020, 2021. And the thing I had heard at the time was for some types of crimes, let's say the most severe non-cybercrime-related stuff you see on the Dark Web that involves human safety or exploitation, law enforcement would very much work together and for the very, very worst of the criminals, they would work together and get the folks publishing certain materials taken down immediately. On the cybercrime side, on the drug side, what have you, I had heard that maybe there was a slightly more competitive or keep-to-yourself aspect between law enforcement agencies where maybe some of the sharing wouldn't happen.Fast-forward to today, and I think about all of the operations where these international agencies and Europol are working together to take down individual ransomware operators. Do you feel there's been an increase in that public-private, but also public-public, sector collaboration in terms of taking out threat actors?Keith JarvisRight, yeah, there's traditionally been a lot of cooperation when it came to, you know, things like you said, like CSAM, like human trafficking, like counterterrorism. There's been a lot of cooperation between governments that traditionally wouldn't cooperate on just about anything else because they see it as a net benefit to both. But then you get to see the personalities and geopolitical considerations of those governments come out when you're talking about other types of crimes. And cybercrime being one that, you know, it's a dangerous business being an American cybercriminal or a British cybercriminal, but we know that Russia, for example, really gets carte blanche to their cybercriminal underground to carry out attacks against anybody so long as they keep it outside of borders, keep it outside of their political allies.There's not a lot of cooperation there when we talk about going after cybercriminal groups. If an American agency were to go to the Russian Federation and say, we think this conspiracy is running out of a data center in St. Petersburg, they may say, thanks, we'll take a look at it, but that's the end of it. But I think we've seen a lot more diverse jurisdictions throughout the world that say, You know what, cybercrime is just a problem, period. And so you start to see a lot more governments that normally wouldn't cooperate with European or US North American agencies that are starting to do that.And likewise, I think on the public-private partnership, certainly the government's been doing more outreach to try and get engaged with companies like us, with Sophos, and before that, Secureworks, and other leaders in information security to say, We know that you're doing valuable research. We know that you have unique insights into, for example, customer networks. You can see things that are going on in the world that, as a government agency, even though we collect signals, that we just can't see that sort of thing that's happening.We have unique insights, and we're going to try and pass data. We're going to try and declassify it and pass it to you. But likewise, we'd like to hear what's happening from your perspective. And there's been a lot more engagement from both sides. That here in the United States, in England and abroad, more agencies are willing to build those relationships. And I guess the jury's still out on whether or not that's been really effective. But I think it's a trend that nobody will deny that information sharing is the right thing to do. It's not correct to withhold information just because you've collected it. You've got to make sure that the people who are empowered to take action have access to it; otherwise, you're just collecting for the sake of collecting it.Alexander CulafiAnd I know that there's obviously been a lot of change in the last couple years, but thinking about yourself, DHS, whatever, do you still feel like the channels are pretty well open for you to talk to and work with other cyber stakeholders?Keith JarvisYeah, absolutely. You know, we definitely have a lot of flux in the political system here in the US, but other areas are more stable and we have more stable relationships. But nothing's gone oto haywire over here. We still feel like we can reach out to the various agencies in the US government and have action taken and vice versa. I think they're willing to come to us. It remains to be seen what will happen over the ensuing few years.But I think those relationships take work. They take constant engagement to be fruitful. And that's something that both sides really have to focus on. You can't just have a press release that says, Boy, the public-private partnership is so important, and then not do anything to follow up on that, because that's pointless. I think those relationships exist and they're working to a certain degree. But we've got to stay on top of it.Alexander CulafiSure. Going back to the offensive side of targeting threat actors as researchers and law enforcement, as everyone has gotten more aggressive at targeting cybercrime, have you noticed threat actors respond in how they mix their Bitcoins or how they communicate with each other or how they sell data or how they get affiliates or whatever? Have you noticed them respond in how they sort of navigate these Dark Web ecosystems, or is it much of the same old same old?Keith JarvisYeah, so once a threat group has established procedures, they don't like to deviate from that because it takes extra work to figure out another way of doing things. And if something works, why fix something that's not broken? Especially if it's just to evade a perceived threat from a threat intelligence company that's tracking them. But I think where we've seen a lot of that sort of change is with financial sanctions from, like, OFAC and similar organizations where they say, If you're going to pay a ransom, you cannot pay this sanctioned entity. And a lot of those ransomware groups that would establish a brand and then stick with it and you could identify those, you know, those attacks quite easily have been forced, because of those sanctions to change branding, to change their procedures when they're breaching a company to make things look differently, at least for a few weeks to keep up the guise so that while the ransom is being negotiated and possibly paid out, that no one's the wiser that this is a sanctioned group.I think one of the key examples of that is Evil Corp, who have run numerous ransomware operations for the last seven, eight years, where they've had to rebrand multiple times because they're on that sanctioned list. They've really had to out of necessity because of the lawyers, right? They have to make it look like it's somebody else. Because really, I mean, no organization, no matter how up against the wall they are, they can't violate the sanctions, right? The consequences are just too grave for them to ignore it.Alexander CulafiAs everyone's been trying to figure out how to get victims to pay the ransom less often over the years, has the economic sanctions piece been a fairly effective effort at even just slowing it down a little bit?Keith JarvisYeah, in cases where it's been applied, it's been pretty effective. But I think the problem is the tempo of the cybercriminal ecosystem, especially for ransomware, just so far outstrips what the government has been doing. That's the problem, is that gap between how quickly they can deploy sanctions versus what's actually happening on the ground. But when they do it, it's pretty effective. I think everyone would be keen to see that happen more from not just the US government but for other governments where a lot of these ransomware victims reside.Alexander CulafiSure. And then going back to your side of things, the research side, I saw Sophos in June, some of your fellow researchers sort of published research about using AI to identify cybercriminals on the Dark Web. And I wanted to ask you about that if you could speak to it, but also just the other ways that you and other researchers are trying to make the identification and attribution of threat actor operations more effective.Keith JarvisRight, yeah. It's an exciting time for us coming from the Secureworks CTU and merging with Sophos after the acquisition because we've got two different security teams that have been doing very similar work in different ways. And we're now trying to zipper those two things together and figure out what works for them, what works for us. And this is some research that came from the Sophos side. And then the Secureworks CTU side, we've been doing Dark Web research for a number of years. This sort of network analysis approach they've used with AI was really neat technology.One of the problems we've really confronted with our Dark Web collection over the years is how to take that data and normalize it in a way that you can sort of interrogate it, how they've done it with network analysis. We've often relied on our individual researchers, subject matter experts really being familiar with the threat actors, the platforms and knowing who has a high reputation, who doesn't. But what they found with the research with AI is sometimes you can tease out those details just from interrogating the raw data and saying who's connected to who, what terms are folks using, what are they selling and build out those sorts of networks of who's who in the Dark Web or in the forums. And that's really important research, that scalability aspect of it.It's really important to have those subject matter experts that are, day to day, going through that data, as miserable as that may be for them. There's so much data out there, it's a fire hose. When we're not, you know, we have to establish what our priorities are, what are we trying to learn from these networks, these forums, and then we go after that with human interaction. But if you can take that data, raw, and just say, point an LLM at it and say, give me what insights you can draw from this data. And that's just going to get better the more that we're able to tag and normalize this data and really put it into a machine-readable format. So we are really excited for that sort of network investigation, that network aspect of it.Alexander CulafiWould it be fair to say then that if the data you're taking in isn't necessarily changing so much and some of the investigation methods you're using are kind of similar to what they've always been, what this LLM stuff and what some of this more modern technology is able to do is to take a lot of this data, make it meaningful quickly, take a lot of the more busy, repetitive work out of it, and then help you sort of make decisions on it a little sooner than you might've been able to otherwise?Keith JarvisYeah, absolutely. I think that's how most people today are really getting value out of these AI platforms is exactly what you said. Tell me the insights and I'll tell you as an expert on the data if I agree with those, and I can identify the so-called hallucinations, I can tell you the junk the system has pumped out. But at the same time, for every piece of junk that one of these systems pumps out, it's also pumping out a valuable insight.It's something that maybe you haven't considered before or a piece of data that you neglected to fully hunt down. It's the force magnifier. It's another tool in the toolbox for folks who are going through a tremendous amount of data to be able to make sense of it in a scalable way.Alexander CulafiI don't want to make it sound like a job interview where I'm like, think of a time when this happened, but could you tell me an example just so I have a better idea of how, what kind of data you would take in here and then how you would act upon it. I think the Dark Web's a great sort of microcosm to drill in on here.Keith JarvisRight. Yeah, so what we're looking for is person names. We're looking for any sort of technical artifacts that they may post, like a Tox ID or another account. We're talking about Onion addresses for leak sites or for other types of marketplaces. We're looking at the reputation that they have on these forums. Most forums have a way to say this person has a high reputation. They have money in escrow, which means they're not just a cutout account. They may have reviews from other vendors or other customers on the site, their longevity on the site. And again, that sort of network analysis that our colleagues perform there to say who's connected to who. You take all that data, and you can sort of build up a picture of who's doing what.That's been the key focus of our groups is on the attribution level is to say, We can attribute this cluster of activity of malware to this group. Now let's go match that up with what we're seeing on real networks, real network traffic, real endpoint data and say this is what they're actually attacking. These are the verticals or geographies that they're actually attacking. So that's been a big focus point for us is to be able to match up what we're seeing on the Dark Web versus what we're actually seeing in actual victim networks.Alexander CulafiI would imagine that this kind of technology would be very helpful for the Bitcoin-tracking component of it, where if you plug in an address, I wouldn't be surprised if just the way Bitcoin works, if that wouldn't just save a ton of time.Keith JarvisYeah, well, I think the benefit of the Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency blockchains is it's a rather, you know, verbose record of what's happened. You don't even really have to go in there and draw unique insights. You can see if you suspect a transaction happens, you can go verify that it did and then what amount and what time and who verified it and where it came from. I think that the key to being successful in those sorts of investigations is having data, the attribution data upfront is to say, OK, we have a busy incident response practice and we've done a hundred ransomware cases this quarter. And we know the wallets that are associated with these threat groups or where the victims pay. And that's otherwise non-public information that wouldn't be known to anyone but the threat actors and the victim. And having that sort of attribution, that tagging, that's when you can really start to build up those relationship networks and say, I understand that this is going into a coin mixing service, but the output addresses are going to a certain ransomware group or another threat group. And I guess you could use AI. I haven't done this, but you could use AI to, go through, which is a lot of data, and then draw up those insights for you. But for the most part, it's a pretty straightforward investigation.Alexander CulafiAs we wrap up a little bit, I wanted to think a little bit about the security customer, the defender, where if I'm someone looking to buy a security product and I'm going to 15 vendor sites, I know this probably used to be a lot more common than it is now, but you would see things that are like Dark Web monitoring, we track the Dark Web. Sometimes as a slight scare tactic, sometimes as shorthand for a lot of more complicated stuff. And then there's obviously real data and infrastructure that does exist on hidden services. But as a defender, what should I know about the Dark Web? What should I worry about? And what's the context I should think about it in so that I'm thinking about it less is like a marketing term and more as something I can consider appropriately?Keith JarvisRight, yeah, and certainly it is a marketing term in many regards. And I don't want to oversell this as a security company that does Dark Web monitoring, right? But I think you have to ask yourself, what is it that you as an organization think might be out there that you are worried about? Is it because of a breach? Is it just because of general security posture that you want to know what's out there? And have an idea of if you were to get Dark Web monitoring, what are you hoping to find or to not find and how does that improve your security posture?And I think the ideal solution for the overwhelming number of customers is to have at least one security vendor in your stable of other security vendors that has some sort of capability where you can go and ask those questions, even if it's not like a Dark Web monitoring SKU that's on your contract, but at least you have some subject matter experts in one of your vendors that you can say, Look, we had a breach. We're interested to see if any of our credentials or any of our data has popped up on any of these leak sites, any of these forums and stuff like that. Have somebody you can go to. But if you do identify things that you want constant measurement of, if you have credentials, if you want a weekly report, if you have credentials out there, then yeah, it's probably time to contract with an actual monitoring firm to get that data.But for most people, it's going to be the sort of one-off question or periodic evaluation, but not like a regular evaluation. And one thing I would caution people to maybe not do, because I'll find out exactly how hard it is, is to try to build that capability internally. Like by all means, if you want to go set up an account on a direct web forum, have at it. But if you think you're really going to be able to build those insights internally, I think you'll find out just how difficult it is to really get useful intelligence out of that without a really well-structured program. But I also don't want to dissuade anyone from pursuing that if they want to.Alexander CulafiYou make a really good point there too, in that maybe folks will sell it, you know, as a SKU, as a separate billable thing or whatever, that they're doing Dark Web monitoring. But I imagine that if someone's looking into a major security vendor, not to speak for all of them, but if you're looking into a major security vendor that's offering some kind of threat monitoring or what have you, whether it's called Dark Web monitoring or not, stolen credentials are probably going to be part of the package regardless. Would it be fair to say that orgs should maybe think less in terms of "Is it on the Dark Web?" and think more in terms of, are you looking for stolen credentials? Are you looking for all this other data that would be relevant for me? Which is inevitably going to be on the Dark Web, but it's not really the point.Keith JarvisYeah, I think at this point it's kind of table stakes for a mature threat intelligence company to have that capability internally and bake that into services that you're providing, the intelligence that you're providing to your customers. Like if one of your major security vendors doesn't have that capability, that's a big question mark because we've got three, four people working full time just on Dark Web monitoring and I'm not even one of them, but it's not really a service that we sell to any great degree. It's just because we need to have that context, that intelligence to build out our picture of the threat landscape, but also to see what's happening, what's new, to make sure those detections and protections get into the product and get communicated to our customers. So it's not even really a revenue-generating service line. It's just something we feel is necessary to do to be competent at what we're trying to achieve here.Alexander CulafiExcellent. And with that, I would say that was a great conversation. Thank you very much, Keith. I really appreciate this tour through how you're looking at the Dark Web, how law enforcement's looking at the Dark Web, and how things have changed a little bit over time.Keith JarvisYeah, thank you so much. Was a pleasure talking to you.Becky BrackenI'm really struck. You guys covered a lot of turf in a small amount of time. I've learned a lot. I'm going to have to sit with a lot of it, but it was an excellent conversation. Thank you so much, Keith, for lending your deep expertise to this conversation, and Alex for your thoughtful questions. That was wonderful. Thank you.Alexander CulafiThank you.Becky BrackenWith that, this has been our latest episode of Dark Reading Confidential. It's a podcast from the editors of Dark Reading, bringing you real life stories straight from the cyber trenches. Thank you all for joining, and we'll see you next time.Read more about:CISO CornerAbout the AuthorDark Reading StaffDark ReadingDark Reading is a leading cybersecurity media site.See more from Dark Reading StaffKeep up with the latest cybersecurity threats, newly discovered vulnerabilities, data breach information, and emerging trends. summary: The article appears to revolve around a podcast discussing the complexities of the Dark Web. Experts talk about how cybercriminals use it for various illicit activities such as selling malware and data leaks. The conversation also covers the rising collaboration between law enforcement agencies in tackling cybercrime, the methods for monitoring the Dark Web, and the implications of AI in identifying cybercriminals. Additionally, it hints at the changing dynamics of threat actor behaviors due to increased scrutiny and sanctions, and the importance of digital forensics in cybersecurity.

BEC DefensesVaronis Acquires Email Security Provider SlashNext to Enhance BEC DefensesVaronis Acquires Email Security Provider SlashNext to Enhance BEC DefensesVaronis plans to integrate SlashNext's advanced phishing, BEC, and social engineering attack protection capabilities into its data security platform.Jeffrey Schwartz, Contributing WriterSeptember 3, 20253 Min ReadSource: Nico El Nino via Alamy Stock PhotoVaronis has acquired email security provider SlashNext and plans to add advanced phishing protection to its data security platform. The combination of two companies will provide customers with defenses for phishing and attacks generated by artificial intelligence (AI) sent over email, SMS, and chat messaging services, such as Slack, Teams, Zoom, and WhatsApp. "The combination of SlashNext's multi-channel phishing defense and Varonis' end-to-end approach to data security — including AI security and identity protection — gives customers the platform they need to detect early signs of compromise and stop attacks long before data is impacted," wrote Varonis CEO and co-founder Yaki Faitelson in a blog post announcing the acquisition. SlashNext deploys predictive AI models and technologies such as computer vision, natural language processing, and virtual browsers to identify, remove, and block phishing and social engineering attacks across email and collaboration platforms. In a statement, Varonis cited statistics from The Tolly Group, an independent testing firm for cybersecurity tools, indicating that SlashNext had a 99% overall detection accuracy and a 100% detection rate for business email compromise (BEC) and QR code attacks. "We put a protective bubble using what we call generative-driven AI around the user, so anywhere that user can be messaged, we're going to protect them," said SlashNext CEO Patrick Harr during a video interview with Dark Reading at RSAC Conference in 2023. Related:Microsoft Lays Out Its Quantum-Safe PlansWhile several established security companies also offer BEC protection — such as Abnormal Security, Mimecast, and Proofpoint — Varonis CFO and COO Guy Melamed says SlashNext is a more reliable offering. "We looked at the accuracy rates, and SlashNext is really, really high in comparison to some of the existing companies that are already out there," he maintains. "We've checked this technology and found it to be best-in-class. We wouldn't have done the acquisition otherwise, and this is a market that can be sold in combination with the Varonis platform in the very near future."According to Melamed, the BEC protection capabilities will be integrated into Varonis's platform during the fourth quarter of this year. "It's a mature technology," he says.Prior to this acquisition, Varonis had already added basic email monitoring capabilities to its data security posture management (DSPM) offering, introduced early last year to provide customers with unified data classification, access governance, and threat detection in hybrid environments. The platform's email monitoring capabilities included discovery and classification of sensitive message content, tracking access and permission updates, and issuing alerts when it discovers unusual actions, such as unsanctioned forwarding and policy violations.Related:Researchers Warn of 'Hidden Risks' in Passwordless Account RecoveryThe SlashNext acquisition is Varonis's second transaction this year. In March, Varonis acquired database activity monitoring (DAM) provider Cyral in a deal valued at approximately $25 million. The Cyral acquisition facilitated last week's release of Varonis Next-Gen DAM, which is now available with the Varonis Data Security Platform. Varonis Next-Gen DAM is designed to protect databases from queries generated from bots and malicious AI-based agents."The [Cyral] acquisition gave us the ability to protect additional platforms that we haven't covered before," Melamed says. Varonis aims further to widen its messaging protection capabilities with the SlashNext deal.The cash and stock deal is valued at up to $150 million, depending on how many SlashNext employees Varonis retains. Most of the 100 employees work in the United Kingdom. In a LinkedIn post on Tuesday, Harr indicated that he will not be joining Varonis and is transitioning out of the CEO role he has held since 2020.Related:SentinelOne Acquires AI Startup Prompt SecurityAbout the AuthorJeffrey SchwartzContributing WriterJeffrey Schwartz is a journalist who has covered information security and all forms of business and enterprise IT, including client computing, data center and cloud infrastructure, and application development for more than 30 years. Jeff is a regular contributor to Channel Futures. Previously, he was editor-in-chief of Redmond magazine and contributed to its sister titles Redmond Channel Partner, Application Development Trends, and Virtualization Review. Earlier, he held editorial roles with CommunicationsWeek, InternetWeek, and VARBusiness. Jeff is based in the New York City suburb of Long Island.See more from Jeffrey SchwartzKeep up with the latest cybersecurity threats, newly discovered vulnerabilities, data breach information, and emerging trends. title: Ore Formation Processes, Part Two: Hydrothermal Boogaloo
content:
There’s a saying in mine country, the kind that sometimes shows up on bumper stickers: “If it can’t be grown, it has to be mined.” Before mining can ever start, though, there has to be ore in the ground. In the last edition of this series, we learned what counts as ore (anything that can be economically mined) and talked about the ways magma can form ore bodies. The so-called magmatic processes are responsible for only a minority of the mines working today. Much more important, from an economic point of view, are the so-called “hydrothermal” processes.
Come back in a few million years, and Yellowstone will be a great mining province.Image: “Gyser Yellowstone” by amanderson2, CC BY 2.0
When you hear the word “hydrothermal” you probably think of hot water; in the context of geology, that might conjure images of Yellowstone and regions like it : Old Faithful geysers and steaming hot springs. Those hot springs might have a role to play in certain processes, but most of the time when a geologist talks about a “hydrothermal fluid” it’s a lot hotter than that.
Is there a point on the phase diagram that we stop calling it water? We’re edging into supercritical fluid territory, here. The fluids in question can be hundreds of degrees centigrade, and can carry things like silica (SiO2) and a metal more famous for not dissolving: gold. Perhaps that’s why we prefer to talk about a “fluid” instead of “water”. It certainly would not behave like water on surface; on the surface it would be superheated steam. Pressure is a wonderful thing.
Let’s return to where we left off last time, into a magma chamber deep underground. Magma isn’t just molten rock– it also contains small amounts of dissolved gasses, like CO2 and H2O. If magma cools quickly, the water gets trapped inside the matrix of the new rock, or even inside the crystal structure of certain minerals. If it cools slowly, however? You can get a hydrothermal fluid within the magma chamber.

Peg It as a Pegmatite
This can create what’s called a pegmatite deposit. Strictly speaking, “pegmatite” refers to rock with a specific texture; when we’re talking about ore, we’re almost always referring to granitic pegmatites: that is, granite rocks with this texture. That texture is big crystals: centimeter size or bigger. Crystals grow large in a pegmatite deposits in part because of the slow cooling, but in part because of the action of the hydrothermal fluid that is squeezed out of the slowly-cooling rock.
When you’re using your hammer for scale next to the crystals, you know it’s a pegmatite. This example is from Radium Creek, Arkaroola, South Australia. Image: Geomartin, CC-BY-SA 4.0
Again, we’re talking about a fluid that’s hundreds of degrees Celsius: seriously supercritical stuff. It can carry a lot of ions. Circulating through the magma chamber, this ion-rich fluid brings each crystal all the metal ions it needs to grow to its full potential. Maybe that’s a garnet the size of your fist, or feldspar crystals like pink playing cards. The ions in the fluid can be leftovers from the earlier melt, but may also include material scoured from surrounding rocks.
Aside from the spectacular granite counter tops and semiprecious gems that sometimes come out of these deposits, granitic pegmatites come in two types: lithium-rich and rare-earth element rich. The lithium rich pegmatites are often called LCT deposits, the letters standing for Lithium, Cesium and Tantalum, the metals of interest. Those–especially the first and last–are not exactly metals of low consequence in this electronic era. That goes double for the rare-earth elements. Especially in North America, there’s a great deal of active prospecting searching for these increasingly valuable deposits.
Mica capacitors. You can’t make these guys without mica, and granitic pegmatites are a good source.Image: Mataresephotos, CC-BY-3.0
Mines have been sunk to extract boron, fluorine, tin, and uranium from pegmatite deposits as well. Of particular note to Hackaday readers would be the mineral Muscovite, a course-grained mica often found in pegmatites, among other locales. Muscovite mica has excellent dielectric properties and fractures easily into thin sheets, making it very useful in capacitors and high voltage applications. The high thermal stability and voltage tolerance of mica capacitors makes them invaluable even today in niche applications, even though ceramics have taken over most of their original uses.
One thing to note about these deposits is that they are not necessarily going to be restricted to Earth. Don’t let the “hydro” in “hydrothermal” fool you– this process is occurring deep underground, in a magma chamber with no access to any surface water. The H2O involved is coming up from the mantle, and the mantle of every rocky body does contain trace water. That even holds true for the Earth’s moon; while older sources will declare that no hydrothermal processes are possible there, newer work has led to a reevaluation of how “wet” lunar rock really is, and re-opened the possibility of lunar pegmatites. Given that, there’s no reason not to expect the process to be at work on every rocky body in the solar system. Look for granitic rock, and you might find an interesting pegmatite.
Orogenic Ores
If the hydrothermal fluid stays put in a magma chamber, it can create pegmatite deposits, but if it breaks free, you’ll find something completely different. Running through faults, fissures, and cracks in the surrounding rock, the somewhat-lower-temperature fluid will have a different mineral content depending both on the melt and the host rock. These hydrothermal vein deposits are sometimes called orogenic ore deposits, because they are often associated with mountain building, which geologists call orogeny.
The white quartz vein follows the fissures in the rock hydrothermal fluid once flowed through. “Main Vein (hydrothermal quartz-gold vein), subsurface exposure in Nalunaq Gold Mine, southern Greenland” by James St. John, CC BY 2.0
That doesn’t mean you need to look near mountains: the gold fields of Kirkland Lake, mentioned last time, are actually an orogenic deposit, and Kirkland Lake sits near the middle of the Canadian Shield, as far from any (modern) mountains as you are likely to find. There may have been mountains there, once, but they were eroded away by the time the Dinosaurs walked the Earth. What you will find there are shocking white veins of quartz shooting through the granite of the Canadian Shield– evidence of the hydrothermal fluid’s ability to carry dissolved silica through fissures of the rock– interspersed with flecks and pebbles of gold. Most gold started in hydrothermal deposits like this one, but in an ironic twist, most of the gold humans have mined is actually from a different type of deposit we’ll get to later. For now we’ll say there are secondary processes at work on this planet and leave it at that.
Native Silver, from a mine that closed in 1887. Image: “Native silver in hydrothermal vein rock (Proterozoic; Silver Islet Mine, Lake Superior, Ontario, Canada) 1” by James St. John, CC BY 2.0
Gold isn’t the only thing to be found in these hydrothermal veins: native silver and copper mines have also been found chasing quartz veins. Cobalt, Molybdenum, even Tin and Tungsten may be found, though not necessarily in native form. To a geologist, note that the word “native” has nothing to do with tribal affiliation, and everything to do with elemental composition. “Native” metals are just that: metals. Native copper is a lump of Cu, not chemically bound into any mineral.
As you might imagine, native metals are among the most desirable of ores, as they often require very little by way of refining. For that reason, until perhaps Greenland or Antarctica’s melting glaciers expose new lands to prospecting, you’re not likely to ever see a new mine producing native copper.
The redox conditions of the fluid are hugely important here: as you might imagine, native metals aren’t going to precipitate from an oxidizing fluid. Redox reactions are hard enough in chemistry class, though; bring them into the world of geochemistry and it gets hugely complicated. Nature is a messy system with too many variables to easily predict.
That’s something many a prospector has found out to his chagrin, for not every vein of quartz will bear metals. On the other hand, enough quartz veins do that “look for veins of quartz” was common advice for prospectors once upon a time. Not all metal-bearing veins may not be entirely quartz, either; many contain quite a lot of carbonate minerals like calcite. The hydrothermal fluid may start out with different amounts of metals dissolved within it, depending on the source magma; it may also scour more or different minerals from the host rocks it flows through. Veins may go on for miles of nothing but quartz before something in composition of the rock, or its temperature, or the pH causes the fluid to start depositing valuable minerals. Geology can be a crapshoot like that.
Of Course It’s More Complex
The above description is somewhat misleading as it makes it sound like vein deposits can only be produced from hydrothermal fluid coming from magma, but that is untrue. It is also possible that surface water (called “meteoric” water by geologists who want to confuse you into thinking about space rocks) can trickle down through fractured rocks until it
Meteoric water has nothing to do with this.Image: Navicore, CC-BY-3.0
reaches a hot-zone and picks up elements by dissolving minerals. A mix of meteoric and “crustal” water (that is, water from magma) may be present in a balance that changes over time. It should also be noted that this water can form a convective circuit, down to the hot zone (or melt) to pick up new minerals, then circulate upwards to deposit them in colder rock. Because this circulating fluid is cooler than in the case of fluids coming directly from a melt (“only” three or four hundred degrees Celsius) , they are sometimes called “epithermal” fluids, and the resulting veiny deposits can be called “epithermal” deposits. Those temperatures are not too far off from what you might find in geyser country. While I’m not suggesting anyone go digging under Old Faithful right now, it might be an interesting locality in a few million years or so.
Epithermal/orogenic/quartz vein deposits don’t need meteoric water– crustal water can be enough–but I have seen no references suggesting they might be found on the Moon. Mars, on the other hand, seems to have every condition required, so there may well be gold in them thar’ Arean hills. Meteorites believed to have come from Vesta show evidence of quartz veinlets as well, so don’t count out larger planetoids when talking about hydrothermal processes either.
There are other high-temperature hydrothermal deposits other than granitic pegmatites we haven’t yet gotten into; there are also several lower-temperature types that are likely to be exclusive to Earth. This entry in our series is getting long enough, however, so we will return to the theme of hydrothermal ore deposits another day.

summary: The article discusses the various geological processes involved in forming ore deposits, particularly focusing on hydrothermal processes and pegmatite deposits. It explains how hydrothermal fluids, under extreme temperatures and pressures in magma chambers, can lead to the formation of valuable minerals like gold and lithium. The article highlights the importance of both magmatic and hydrothermal processes in mining, with emphasis on how minerals can either stay within pegmatite deposits or escape to form other types of ore deposits, such as orogenic and epithermal deposits. Moreover, it touches upon the implications of these processes for mining both on Earth and potentially elsewhere in the solar system, illustrating the complexity and richness of geological formations related to mining.

title: Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge review: More than just super thin
author: Sam Rutherford
summary: The article reviews the Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge, highlighting its sleek and stylish design as a key feature. Despite its thin profile, the phone integrates advanced technology, including a titanium frame and a high-resolution 200MP main camera borrowed from the S25 Ultra. The performance is backed by a Snapdragon 8 Elite chip and it supports advanced features like 120Hz refresh rate and a bright OLED display. However, the device comes with compromises such as the smallest battery in the S25 series and the absence of a telephoto lens. The review reflects on the return of thin designs in smartphones and assesses whether this trend serves practical purposes or simply elicits aesthetic appeal.

title: FDA is using an AI system that staff say frequently invents or misrepresents drug research
content:
The US Food and Drug Administration is relying on Elsa, a generative AI system, to help evaluate new drugs - even though, according to insiders, it regularly fabricates studies.Ad
    
        
            
        
            
    
"Anything that you don’t have time to double-check is unreliable. It hallucinates confidently," one current FDA employee told CNN, describing the AI system known as Elsa (Efficient Language System for Analysis), which is supposed to speed up drug approvals. Several staff members reported that Elsa frequently invents studies or misrepresents research data - a well-known issue with large language models. The FDA's head of AI, Jeremy Walsh, acknowledged the problem: "Elsa is no different from lots of [large language models] and generative AI. They could potentially hallucinate."
Despite these risks, Elsa is already being used to review clinical protocols and assess risks during inspections. The system operates in a regulatory gray area, since there are currently no binding rules for AI in US healthcare.Ad

summary: The article discusses the US Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) use of a generative AI system named Elsa to evaluate new drugs. Despite its potential to expedite drug approvals, insiders express concerns over Elsa's reliability, noting that the system often fabricates studies and misrepresents research data. This issue is characteristic of many large language models. FDA's head of AI, Jeremy Walsh, acknowledges that such AI systems can 'hallucinate', raising questions about their safety and efficacy. Elsa's use in reviewing clinical protocols and conducting risk assessments takes place amid a lack of regulatory guidelines governing AI applications in US healthcare.

            China has proposed a global action plan to govern artificial intelligence, just days after the United States unveiled its own plan to promote US dominance of the rapidly growing field that’s become a key bargaining chip in trade talks between the economic powerhouses.
    

    
            Chinese Premier Li Qiang unveiled China’s vision for future AI oversight at the World AI Conference (WAIC), an annual gathering in Shanghai of tech titans from more than 40 countries.
    


      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  Chinese Premier Li Qiang speaks at the opening ceremony of the World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai on July 26, 2025.
  

          Agatha Cantrill/AFP/Getty Images
        
    
    


    
            “Overall, global AI governance is still fragmented. Countries have great differences, particularly in terms of areas such as regulatory concepts, institutional rules,” said Li in his speech on Saturday. “We should strengthen coordination to form a global AI governance framework that has broad consensus as soon as possible.”
    

    
            Li’s remarks came just days after the Trump administration unveiled its 28-page AI action plan, which aims to remove “bureaucratic red tape” and establish US dominance in the sector.
    

    
            While Li did not directly refer to the US in his speech, he alluded to the ongoing trade tensions between the two superpowers, which include American restrictions on advanced semiconductor exports — a component vital for powering and training AI, which is currently causing a shortage in China.
    

    
            “Key resources and capabilities are concentrated in a few countries and a few enterprises,” said Li in his speech on Saturday. “If we engage in technological monopoly, controls and restrictions, AI will become an exclusive game for a small number of countries and enterprises.”
    


      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  People visit the Shanghai World Expo Exhibition and Convention Center during the World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai, China July 26, 2025.
  

          Go Nakamura/Reuters
        
    
    


    
            AI chips have become a key bargaining tool between US and China in trade negotiations, which continued this week with a meeting in Stockholm. Before the latest round of talks, both countries appeared to make concessions, with Washington lifting its ban on sales of a key Nvidia AI chip to China, and Beijing suspending its antitrust investigation into American chemical firm DuPont.
    

    
            Speaking from Scotland on Sunday, Trump said the US is “very close to a deal with China,” but offered no further details. The current deadline for a deal expires on August 12.
    

  
        Billions spent in global AI race


    
            China has not been shy about promoting its AI ambitions: with more than 5,000 AI companies, and a core AI industry valued at 600 billion yuan ($84 billion) in April 2025, the nation is all-in on its tech rivalry with the US.
    

    
            This surge is being fueled by enormous government and private sector spending. Between 2013 and 2023, state venture capital firms invested an estimated $209 billion into AI-related businesses, according to research published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private think tank based in Massachusetts, and this year alone, public sector spending on AI is expected to top 400 billion yuan ($56 billion).
    

    
            It’s still a fraction of what the US spends — private AI investment in the US reached $109.1 billion in 2024, around 12 times China’s $9.3 billion — but China’s commitment to the AI race is evident in other ways. Since 2017, China has published more patents for generative AI inventions annually than all other countries combined, according to data from the World Intellectual Property Organization.
    


      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  People watch a humanoid robot play boxing at a Unitree booth during the World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai, China July 26, 2025.
  

          Go Nakamura/Reuters
        
    
    


    
            All this investment is narrowing the gap between the US and China in the AI race.
    

    
            Earlier this year, the launch of one-year-old Chinese startup DeepSeek’s new AI model R1 caused chaos on Wall Street and demonstrated China’s technical capabilities by quickly outpacing models by Meta and Anthropic. It was allegedly developed for just $5.6 million, a fraction of the cost spent to make other models like ChatGPT (over $100 million) and Gemini (almost $200 million.)
    

    
            More recently, another startup Moonshot’s Kimi K2 model released earlier this month also sent ripples in the AI community for its lower cost and capabilities that outperform some Google and OpenAI’s models.
    

    
            The rapid development of China’s AI market is even predicted to break even within the next few years, delivering a 52% return on investment as early as 2030, according to research from financial services firm Morgan Stanley.
    

    
            Secretary-General of ASEAN, Dr. Kao Kim Hourn, also called for “robust governance” of artificial intelligence to mitigate potential threats, including misinformation, deepfakes, and cybersecurity threats.
    


      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  People visit a Rokid booth during the World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai, China July 26, 2025.
  

          Go Nakamura/Reuters
        
    
    


    
            “These developments demand urgent, coordinated action from the international community to ensure AI serves human welfare and social good,” he said in his speech at the conference, adding that AI implementation in ASEAN could further expand the region’s rapidly growing digital economy and “increase the region’s GDP by 10-18%.”
    

    
            Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt reiterated the call for international collaboration, explicitly calling on the US and China to work together.
    

    
            “As the largest and most significant economic entities in the world, the United States and China should collaborate on these issues,” said Schmidt at WAIC. “We have a vested interest to keep the world stable, keep the world not at war, to keep things peaceful, to make sure we have human control of these tools.”
    

    
            Other speakers included computer scientist Geoffrey Hinton, sometimes referred to as “the godfather of AI” and French AI researcher and special envoy Anne Bouverot.
    

  
        Latest robot tech displayed


    
            Launched by Singaporean think tank Artificial Intelligence International Institute (AIII), the conference has been held in Shanghai since its inception in 2018 and has been an important platform for Chinese companies to showcase their technology to the world.
    

  



      
          Related article
  
    
        
      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  AlphaBot2 at the Beyond Expo in Macao in May 2025.
  

          Tom Booth/CNN
        
    
    


    
      
        Will a dice-playing robot eventually make you tea and do your dishes?
      
  
      




    
            The event — which in the past has been attended by key figures in the tech industry, including Elon Musk and Jack Ma — features technology exhibitions, expert keynotes and discussion panels in a bid to further AI research, development and governance, something China hopes to play a leading role in.
    

    
            Attended by more than 800 companies, WAIC 2025 was again dominated by Chinese tech firms, including Tencent, Alibaba, SoftBank-backed Keenon Robotics and robotics startup Unitree, with appearances from several major US corporations like Tesla, Alphabet, and Amazon.
    


      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  A cosplayer presents the new AI doll Mochi at the Nubia booth at the Shanghai New Expo Center during the WAIC (World Artificial Intelligence Conference) 2025 in Shanghai, China, on July 28, 2025.
  

          Ying Tang/NurPhoto/Shutterstock
        
    
    



      
    
       
    
    
    
    
        
          
  
  A PsiBot robot plays mahjong during the 2025 World AI Conference (WAIC) and High-Level Meeting on Global AI Governance at Shanghai World Expo Exhibition and Convention Center in Shanghai, on July 27, 2025.
  

          VCG/Getty Images
        
    
    


    
            Visitors explored tech innovations across 3,000 exhibits, which included over 100 new product debuts. They included new AI models from Tencent Holdings and Hong Kong-based company SenseTime, Alibaba’s first AI-powered smart glasses, new popcorn-serving bipedal robot models from Keenon Robotics, and cute companion “pet” robots from Shenzhen startup ZTE.
    

    
            Other key exhibitions at the three-day event included Unitree’s G1 boxing robot, which quickly caught the attention of visitors and became a fan favorite on social media, dancing robot dogs developed by China Mobile, and PsiBot’s mahjong-playing humanoid.

title: Detecting Data Leaks Before Disaster
content:
Sep 03, 2025The Hacker NewsData Protection / Compliance

In January 2025, cybersecurity experts at Wiz Research found that Chinese AI specialist DeepSeek had suffered a data leak, putting more than 1 million sensitive log streams at risk. 
According to the Wiz Research team, they identified a publicly accessible ClickHouse database belonging to DeepSeek. This allowed “full control over database operations, including the ability to access internal data”, Wiz Research stated, with more than a million lines of log streams involved, containing chat history, secret keys and more. 
Wiz immediately reported the issue to DeepSeek, which quickly secured the exposure. Still, the incident underscored the danger of data leakage.
Intentional or unintentional?
Data leakage is a broad concept, covering a range of scenarios. As IBM notes, the term in general refers to a scenario where “sensitive information is unintentionally exposed to unauthorized parties”. 
It could be intentional or unintentional. On the intentional side, for instance, hackers could use phishing or social engineering techniques to manipulate an organization’s employees into exposing their personal data. 
There’s even the risk of an insider threats: for instance, a worker with a grudge who seeks to compromise systems, perhaps for financial benefit or as part of some quest for revenge. 
But unintentional leakage is just as big a concern. This could be a case of simple human error: sending an email to the wrong person or providing too much information to a third party for example.
There are a wide range of common vectors – we’ll run through just a few. 
Misconfigured cloud storage
Cloud misconfigurations can be a common cause of data leakage. The Cloud Security Alliance highlights the danger from simple mistakes, like leaving default passwords in place or failing to properly configure access controls.
Endpoint vulnerabilities
Data processed through hardware like unencrypted laptops or stored in devices such as USBs can be a key vulnerability for leakage; it’s important that employees are aware of – and follow – organizational security policies to mitigate this risk.

Emails and messaging
There’s a real danger that data can be intercepted: this could come from a simple error (sending a sensitive attachment to the wrong address) or through a deliberate attack. Robust encryption is essential to ensure it stays in the right hands. 
Shadow IT
Employees often use their own IT as part of their daily working lives (such as external cloud technologies), including for data storage. While this isn’t generally malicious, it can make risk management more difficult, notes the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), “because you won’t have a full understanding of what you need to protect and what you value most.”
Financial and legal problems
There are several common drivers of data leakage, ranging from weak access controls to a lack of data-classification policies, insufficient monitoring, and inadequate employee training. But no matter the specific cause, the consequences can be devastating. 
For example, regulatory authorities around the world now enforce strict data protection policies, which can result in huge fines for organizations that fail to comply; this includes the EU’s General Daa Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA).
There is also the broader risk of losing intellectual property (IP) or other sensitive company information. Crimes like credit card fraud could stem from a leak, while public companies could even see a fall in their share price. 
Perhaps most importantly, failing to protect employee and customer data could have a devastating impact on an organization’s reputation, with long-term negative implications for the business. 

Building your defenses 
So how can organizations protect themselves, their employees and their customers from the dangers of data leakage? Here are some key approaches:
Enforce least-privilege access: By granting users access only to the data they need to perform their job, the ‘blast radius’ of a breach or leakage will be significantly reduced.
Pursue data loss prevention (DLP): This is a wide-ranging solution, combining technologies like AI and antivirus software with techniques and actions focused on people and processes, all with the aim of identifying and preventing data-connected harm. 
Classify sensitive data: Protection begins with knowledge. Develop a thorough understanding of your riskiest data to ensure you know where to prioritize your security implementation. 
Audits: Through both external audit checks and a comprehensive internal audit program, organizations can increase their chances of identifying potential vulnerabilities. 
Training: Of course, no technical solution or operational enhancement can succeed without full employee engagement and understanding. Adequate training will ensure your staff and other stakeholders are up to speed, while engagement may even produce new insights into vulnerabilities and mitigation techniques.

CompassDRP: Detect leaked data
As your digital attack surface grows, so does the risk of data leakage. Outpost24’s CompassDRP helps organizations manage this expanding threat environment, with a key module focused on data leakage. 
The feature has crucial applications for many businesses. These include:

Detect potentially leaked documents or confidential data: Users often rely on unauthorized or misconfigured applications to share documents and sometimes confidential data with customers or colleagues. The Data Leakage feature is designed to detect such cases across numerous sources, including document repositories. 
Detect potentially leaked source code: Such leakages could reveal internal information to an attacker, including IP or even the authentication tokens in the code. The Data Leakage feature searches code repositories to detect these leaks. 

Organizations of all sizes deal with growing volumes of data today. This is a huge advantage, helping gather insights into your business and your customer base. However, it also poses risks, as we have seen. 
By embracing technological innovation and operational enhancements, you can help ensure your organization realizes the many benefits of this information without succumbing to the dangers and costly consequences of data leakage. Book a CompassDRP live demo.

Johnson, Senior Director, Enterprise SecuritySeptember 5, 20254 Min ReadSource: Song_about_summer via Alamy Stock PhotoCOMMENTARYThere's an extreme shortage of cybersecurity talent in the workforce, with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) citing the existing workforce shortage at 3.4 million globally. At a time when digital security is more important than ever, this growing talent shortage poses an extreme risk to public and private entities. In fact, according to the same data from NIST, it's expected that more than half of significant cybersecurity incidents this year will result from a lack of talent or human failure.So, how do we address this shortage? By shoring up the programs that train the next generation of industry talent.Student-Run SOCs: A Model for Workforce DevelopmentThe current industry talent shortage is where student-run security operations centers (SOCs) can come into play. These unique, new-to-market programs offer academic institutions an opportunity to defray the costs often associated with SOC operations, shoring up their cybersecurity systems while providing students with hands-on experience that translates into marketable skills upon graduation.In Louisiana, a first-of-its-kind student-run SOC is leading the charge across 34 Louisiana State University (LSU) campuses, utilizing a whole-of-state approach to cybersecurity. Launched in 2023, LSU's program recruits students from all disciplines, not just cybersecurity and IT, to work on the SOC with continuous support and training from TekStream through its MDR service, which uses Splunk's SIEM/SOAR software deployed on AWS. The SOC provides 24/7 security coverage across 34 institutions while providing students up to 1,000 hours of frontline security experience each year. Since early 2024, students have worked on approximately 33% of all the SOC's cybersecurity incidents.Related:Czech Warning Highlights China Stealing User DataAs part of this innovative model, students are taught by industry veterans how to manage the LSU SOC using Splunk technology. Students are trained at the same level as TekStream employees on cyberattacks, analysis, network defense, policy and escalation, and real-time response tactics to actual incidents. This means they gain valuable experience in professional roles that are in high demand while completing their studies.This not only serves as an excellent opportunity to take a lower-cost approach to training new talent, but it also provides an opportunity for LSU to train and upskill current IT staff. In the long term, this will help LSU and other private and public entities address existing labor shortages driving up labor costs in both the public and private sectors. The first three graduates of the program, Class of December 2024, have all gone on to pursue careers in cybersecurity as full-time TekStream employees.Related:Japan, South Korea Take Aim at North Korean IT Worker ScamBenefits of a Student-Run SOCIn addition to serving as an excellent resource for training and upskilling industry talent, student-run SOCs provide additional benefits. For one, student-run SOCs also offer an affordable, scalable source of on-site talent for academic institutions looking to grow or bolster their cybersecurity programs, especially if they want to take a whole-of-state approach.Additionally, it provides a unique and competitive educational offering for students looking for a successful cybersecurity career post-graduation. Those who partake in the program receive a transcript upon completion that helps them directly transition to the job market. This is an added boon for students looking to enter the field, as it provides a leg-up during the interview and job-offer negotiation process compared with students from other universities.Lastly, the student-run SOC at LSU acts as a scalable model that can be leveraged by other entities, both private and public, around the globe to improve our overall cybersecurity infrastructure. Other academic institutions, like the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT), are already implementing similar programs across their campuses.Related:Hybrid Clouds Provide a Practical Approach to Post-Quantum MigrationImproved CybersecurityThe benefits of the student-run SOC don't end with an upskilled workforce. Through public-private partnerships like the one between LSU, TekStream, Splunk, and AWS, LSU transitioned from a reactive to a proactive security model. That's because, with this structure, LSU gains access to better automation, increased threat sharing and remediation using a whole-of-state approach and consistency with their architecture. At the same time, their costs are lower than a standalone approach and they're able to leverage AI in their cybersecurity program, helping to tackle the barrier-of-entry AI has created for many new grads.Strengthening Public-Private Collaboration for a Secure FutureAccording to a House Committee on Homeland Security data snapshot, cyberattacks on critical infrastructures increased 30% worldwide in 2023. The number of cyberattacks will only grow with the time we spend online and the data we create.Securing and training the next generation of cybersecurity talent is where the future lies for successfully addressing existing talent gaps. Long-term, student-run SOCs provide an educational, scalable approach to cybersecurity resilience that will help public and private entities future-proof their cybersecurity.The LSU student-run SOC is an excellent example of the importance of partnerships between academia, government, and private sector organizations to drive innovation and long-term workforce development. With more programs like the student-run SOC, we can expand our cybersecurity workforce and better secure our public and private entities for when, not if, cyberattacks occur.Read more about:CISO CornerAbout the AuthorBruce JohnsonSenior Director, Enterprise SecurityBruce Johnson has more than 38 years of experience in the information technology industry, including security, infrastructure architecture, software development, and management of multiple portfolios. He has experience in Splunk, security solutions, cloud migration, portal, content workflow, integration, and project management. title: France Ousts Second PM in One Year
content:
France’s National Assembly ousted Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday in a 364-194 no-confidence motion.

The Details: Bayrou called the vote of confidence on himself while trying to pass a controversial national budget that would include $44 billion (euros) in cuts. The vote was reportedly bipartisan, and 25 Members of Parliament (MPs) abstained. French President Emmanuel Macron is expected to accept Bayrou’s official resignation on Tuesday and appoint a new prime minister in the coming days. On Wednesday, anti-government protests are set to take place throughout France.

For Context: Former Prime Minister Michel Barnier was subject to a no-confidence motion in December, making Monday’s events the second ousting in ten months. Prior to that, the last no-confidence motion was in 1962.

How The Media Covered It: News outlets across the political spectrum were pessimistic towards the future of the French economy and political system. NBC (Lean Left bias) asserted, “Though Macron remains a big presence internationally — leading European efforts to support Ukraine and provide a counterweight to President Donald Trump — at home he is dogged by a divided electorate and long-term uncertainty.” A BBC (Center) editor stated, “[Bayrou’s] defeat was inevitable - but France's enormous pile of debt remains.” Breitbart (Right) said Macron “can either attempt to install another prime minister and continue the fight within the deeply divided National Assembly, or he can dissolve the parliament and call fresh legislative elections.”

Written by the AllSides staff (of humans). Learn more. Support our mission. Suggest an improvement to this summary.
